comments.commentBody:
Not sure about this one. On the one hand it is depressing to think that Mr. Ed premiered 50 years ago today. On the other hand the theme was solid and the puzzle not too difficult. I suppose this was fun for Mr. Ed fans. I never was and never watched it and never thought the premise of the show was funny. Time to go to bed and have the nurse tuck me in….

Go Bears

Arkansas is making a game of it, so I can't go to bed. Just for fun I created some word trees from the NumberPlay Text dataset.

NumberPlay Text Word Tree Starting from Question
NumberPlay Text Word Tree Ending at Question
NumberPlay Text Word Tree Starting from Answer
NumberPlay Text Word Tree Ending at Answer

I usually start with 1A, and tab through the across clues filling in those I'm sure of, perhaps confirming answers as I go with some down clues. About 10 clues in, I check the byline. "Ah, no wonder I'm having trouble," I might say to myself at that point. So I had already filled in 17A by the time I saw the byline here.
No troubles with this puzzle, though - the letters jumped right into the grid.

When I solve on paper, though, I usually start with clues that have blanks, and then build on those answers. And for some reason, I often find myself completing the right side of the puzzle before the left. In AcrossLite, I read the clues from the top of the page rather than from the clue columns, so am more focused on them individually. Does that make sense?

I enjoyed Mr. Ed as a kid, as well as Rocky and Bullwinkle. Fun to remember them here!

No, parents who home school their children do not "have to" shoulder all of their child's educational expenses. They choose to do so. And the choice they make is detrimental to their children, as they deprive the child of the most important value of attending school, which is to help socialize the child and prepare them to deal with other people in the real world. If parents want to choose that route for their children, that is their right, but we should not be asked to subsidize that bad decision.

http://www.winningprogressive.org
How many inner-city schools could afford these? Probably none. Once again, education in America proves itself to be a privilege for the rich.

I have a netbook with a 140 gb hard drive, keyboard, etc. It cost $300. Why are schools wasting so much money on the IPad? It would be great for students to have all their textbooks on devices like this, but it is important to remember that they are just tools, not entertainment. Kids have to learn to think, and that doesn't just come from a computer screen. I also cannot wait to see kids come in without having done their homework, saying their "batteries went dead"...

This is an online article in a technology blog, right? Why are so many posters shocked to hear that people rely on their cellphones for alarm clocks? I haven't owned an alarm clock since 2001, when I got my first cellphone (a giant brick compared to today's), and I've never had a problem that wasn't my own fault (hitting snooze).
I'm not a morning person, and cellphones allow you to set multiple alarms (just in case I happen to doze off again), at different times on different days, and automatically. (As an added bonus, I generally think I'm getting a phone call, which wakes me up more than the "DAN DAN DAN" noise of normal alarms). I have a phone that runs on Android, so I didn't have this problem--but I'd be furious if I did.

Of course, I don't own a landline, cd player/walkman or calculator, either.

Some people just feel entitled to everything.  These guys have rich parents, Harvard education, they are Olympic athletes, and they have a $140M settlement for an idea that they spent a little bit of time in college (probably in between chasing cute girls).   In case they dont get it, there is a big difference between having an idea and actually executing it.  Even if they had the idea, Zuckerberg (and the people who came to run Facebook) executed it. The brothers got their money, now they just have to fade into woodwork and enjoy their court-won megabucks instead of looking like spoiled brats to everyone who reads the press.

I am NEVER late for work but I was half an hour late for work one day because of this problem. My iPhone 4 alarm works for a while, but then it will randomly not go off on some days. I have to use my iPod Touch, which does not have this problem, as a backup alarm.

Some real reasons why Apple is positioned better, (especially in regard to some silly criticisms from number 2 for instance):

1. Recently purchased? That's because a lot of people already had iPhones.

2. Apple has 1 phone. Some people don't like it/can't get it (Just AT&T). Android has diverse phones, so people will be able to personalize their hardware choices and may sacrifice what even THEY, as Android users, see as a better OS in the iPhone, for that specific choice from the array of Android hardware.

Help me please.

Can someone elaborate on how I could obtain this malfunction? I have an iPhone, and unfortunately, it has continued to work fine. I have an important day at work tomorrow, and it would really help if i could show up late. Also, I have a flight later in the week that I would love to miss. I desperate here.
@freerange: psst: iPad is not a phone.

After a $1000 personal experience relating to a missed flight and an unexpected rental car journey of 550 miles thanks to no wake-up alarm from my iPhone 4, I would like to know if Mr. Jobs' antenna is also not working properly. Obviously he was not "tuned in" to the fact that a simple broadcast text or email from Apple or ATT to iPhone users could have averted a great deal of inconvenience, expense and even anguish on the part of some customers. I know (because Jobs told me so) that the antenna is not the problem on the i4; we we are simply "holding the phone wrong". As for expectations, we also seem to be holding Jobs wrong as well by assuming he too would work properly instead of allowing his customers to define the problem for his company (again). Apple has become too comfortable with its large number of customers who mindlessly fail to hold the company to the high standards it professes by continuing to purchase its products. Too many great products available to accept Apple's superior price, questionable dependability and obvious lack of customer focus.

"Boss, I didn't wake up because my clock has a software bug"
Now I know I'm getting old, when the clocks I remember from my youth didn't even consume power, they had to be wound up every couple of days.

I'm sad for the Winkelvosses. They are presumably bright and talented men. Had they never met Mark Zuckerberg, their website would likely still not have have taken off (most don't) and they would have moved on to happy and productive lives doing something else. As it is, their lives will be defined by bitterness and resentment. Neither $140 million nor $14 billion will give their lives meaning if they can't move beyond Facebook.

The alarm seems to work on my iPhone 4 most of the time, the only time there seems to be a problem is when the phone is charging?? Did the same thing with my iPhone 3... These phones are very expensive and yes, the alarms should work ALL THE TIME! There should be no need to set up several alarm clocks. I'm not complaining though. A glitch is a glitch and hopefully Apple will fix this very soon.... I have faith the issue will be resolved quickly!

I have several video cameras and shoot a lot of production video and my tip is to buy the biggest and fastest card you can afford. Also, buy a name-brand card, don't try to save money on the cheap off-brans. The speed of the card can make a real difference in smoothing out your video. If you're video looks "choppy", chances are your card isn't fast enough to suck in the data at the speed the camera can dish it out.
FYI, there are class 10 SDHC cards.
"White coat syndrome" is two things. Either one worries about seeing the doctor or one calms down. My blood pressure is always lower when my doctor takes it.
@Dr Klein (#4)  That $2500 you received would, I believe, qualify today as an illegal kickback.

Thank you for a very interesting article. I must say, though, a good friend of mine watches the Netflix Wii channel on her TV through her Wii and loves it. They haven't had any problems with quality on their big screen TV.

If the device accurately tracks your BP, great. But there are many others that can do it attached to your computer with out your iphone just as well.

Frankly, after 5 years of tracking my blood pressure daily, I have cycled through all the electronic methods back to the manual arm cuff and stethoscope . No batteries and it always works correctly.

The range of results on electronic methods just show the meaninglessness. Or more correctly, the deviation of readings negated the certainty of the mean.

As a PS to my last comment:
Am I assured that Dr. Andrew Brandeis is not compensated in anyway from the vendor?
I suspect he is.

If I am wrong, please assure me of same and I will withdraw my comment assuming he has good intentions and is just not aware of the universe of less expensive alternatives.
Now all we need is a similar service that lets you call FROM other countries into the USA for free!

Free is always nice (hard to argue with free), but there is no way you should be paying $2.50/min for calls to Paris otherwise.

For example, I use a service called Localphone that lets you call internationally for really cheap, for example, it's $0.009/min for calls to France, the UK, etc.
And, you can set up local access numbers so you never have to dial pins, etc.

At $0.009/min, why bother messing with FreePhone2Phone?
